title: 103_hr3575
content: The Animal Enterprise Protection Act of 1993 may be cited as the ``Animal Enterprise Protection Act of 1993''. This Act ensures freedom of access to animal enterprises. Chapter 13 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section, Sec. 248, which prohibits activities that involve blocking access to animal enterprises through force, threat of force, or physical obstruction. Violators will face penalties and civil remedies. The new section, Sec. 248 of Chapter 13 of title 18, United States Code, imposes penalties for offenses related to blocking access to animal enterprises. For a first offense, individuals may face a fine, imprisonment up to 1 year, or both. For second or subsequent offenses, penalties increase to a fine, imprisonment up to 3 years, or both. If bodily injury occurs, imprisonment can be up to 10 years, and in case of death, the sentence can be for any term of years or life. Civil actions can be taken by aggrieved individuals under this section. The Attorney General can obtain relief in a civil action for violations of the section. State attorneys general can also take civil actions for violations. The court can award various types of relief, including injunctive relief and damages for aggrieved persons. The court may award statutory damages of $5,000 per violation and reasonable fees for attorneys and expert witnesses to the prevailing party. This section does not prohibit protected expressive conduct and does not provide exclusive remedies or preempt state legislation. Definitions include "animal enterprise." The term "animal enterprise" encompasses commercial or academic entities using animals for various purposes, including food production, research, and entertainment. A "facility" refers to the building where the enterprise is located. "Physical obstruction" involves blocking access to reproductive health service facilities. The term "State" includes individual states within the context. The term 'State' includes individual states within the United States, the District of Columbia, and any commonwealth, territory, or possession. 'Intimidate' is defined as placing a person in reasonable apprehension of bodily harm. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act takes effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and applies only to conduct occurring on or after that date. SEC. 4. CLERICAL AMENDMENT. The table of sections in chapter 13 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new item: "248. Blocking access to animal enterprises."
